topics.title: Refuse Boarding for Trespassers
topics.description: Transit or rail operators refuse boarding to people observed trespassing in the right-of-way or using informal cut-throughs. This creates a direct consequence tied to the transit trip rather than only police enforcement.
topics.notablePractices:
- Coordinate with transit police and operations control centers
- Clearly message the policy at stations and on vehicles
- Pair with education and engineering treatments at chronic trespass locations
topics.advantages:
- Creates a tangible consequence for trespassing behavior
- Can be implemented with existing fare inspection or security staff
- Signals organizational commitment to right-of-way safety
topics.drawbacks:
- Requires consistent documentation and due-process safeguards
- Risk of disproportionate impacts on certain user groups
- May be unpopular if not paired with safer legal routes
topics.references: Federal Railroad Administration. (2010). Community trespass prevention guide. U.S. Department of Transportation. https://railroads.dot.gov

topics.title: Anti-Trespass Panels
topics.description: Textured, uneven surface panels installed along the ballast or shoulder near tracks to make walking across the right-of-way uncomfortable and inconvenient, discouraging casual trespass.
topics.notablePractices:
- Install at known desire lines approaching the tracks
- Pair with fencing and wayfinding to legal crossings
- Maintain visibility for train crews and road users
topics.advantages:
- Strong physical deterrent to walking along or across tracks
- Relatively low profile and compatible with many sites
- Can complement traditional fencing and gates
topics.drawbacks:
- May shift trespass to adjacent locations if used alone
- Installation and maintenance costs in harsh environments
- Not suitable where regular maintenance access is needed on foot
topics.references: Ogden, B. D., & Cooper, C. (2019). Highway-rail crossing handbook (3rd ed., Report No. FHWA-SA-18-040/FRA-RRS-18-01). Federal Highway Administration & Federal Railroad Administration.

topics.title: Pedestrian-Specific Gate
topics.description: Gates designed for pedestrian movements at crossings, often narrower and lower than vehicle gates, that close across sidewalks or paths when trains approach.
topics.notablePractices:
- Coordinate timing and clearance with existing warning systems
- Provide clear tactile and visual cues for people with disabilities
- Avoid designs that trap users between tracks
topics.advantages:
- Creates a very clear stop line for people on foot
- Reduces likelihood of pedestrians entering the crossing during activation
- Can be retrofitted at many existing crossings
topics.drawbacks:
- Higher capital and maintenance cost than passive treatments
- Requires reliable activation and fail-safe design
- May be challenging in constrained urban environments
topics.references: Khattak, A. J., et al. (2024). Pedestrian and bicyclist safety at highway-rail grade crossings (Year 1 report). U.S. Department of Transportation.

topics.title: Gate Skirts
topics.description: Vertical panels or mesh attached to the underside of pedestrian or vehicle gates that close the gap between the gate arm and the ground, reducing the ability to duck under.
topics.notablePractices:
- Use materials that are frangible or breakaway if struck
- Ensure skirts do not snag mobility devices or bicycles
- Coordinate with snow clearance and drainage needs
topics.advantages:
- Simple add-on to existing active warning devices
- Strong visual cue that the crossing is fully closed
- Reduces common risky behavior of ducking under gates
topics.drawbacks:
- Additional maintenance exposure to weather and impact
- May collect debris or snow if poorly detailed
- Not effective at uncontrolled trespass locations away from crossings
topics.references: Federal Railroad Administration. (2024). Highway-rail grade crossing and trespassing research. U.S. Department of Transportation.

topics.title: Manual Swing Gates
topics.description: Pedestrian-scale gates that users must push open to pass through, often arranged so they self-close and require deliberate, slower movement before entering the track area.
topics.notablePractices:
- Combine with detectable warnings and signage
- Design for accessibility of mobility devices and strollers
- Use robust hardware to withstand frequent use
topics.advantages:
- Low-tech and relatively low-cost treatment
- Forces users to slow and make a conscious decision
- Can be used where active warning integration is not feasible
topics.drawbacks:
- Can be propped open or defeated if not monitored
- May be difficult for some users with limited upper body strength
- Requires regular inspection of latches and hinges
topics.references: Ogden, B. D., & Cooper, C. (2019). Highway-rail crossing handbook (3rd ed.). Federal Highway Administration & Federal Railroad Administration.

topics.title: Pedestrian Channelization
topics.description: Use of fencing, railings, bollards, and path geometry to guide pedestrians to legal crossings and discourage informal shortcuts across the right-of-way.
topics.notablePractices:
- Extend channelization far enough upstream to intercept desire lines
- Maintain adequate clear width for accessibility
- Combine with wayfinding and visibility improvements at legal crossings
topics.advantages:
- Reduces random crossing locations along the corridor
- Helps concentrate investment and warning devices at legal crossings
- Can be tailored to different urban and rural contexts
topics.drawbacks:
- Can feel restrictive or hostile if overused
- May shift trespass to gaps in the system if not continuous
- Requires ongoing maintenance and graffiti management
topics.references: Federal Railroad Administration. (2010). Community trespass prevention guide. U.S. Department of Transportation.

topics.title: Violation Audio Warning
topics.description: Automated audio messages or alarms triggered when people enter the track area during an active warning phase, calling out the unsafe behavior in real time.
topics.notablePractices:
- Use clear, concise, and locally appropriate language
- Target speakers toward the crossing to limit noise spillover
- Consider pairing with visual messages or beacons
topics.advantages:
- Directly addresses risky behavior at the moment it occurs
- Audible cues can reach distracted users not watching signals
- Provides data if integrated with logging systems
topics.drawbacks:
- Potential noise concerns for nearby residents
- Effectiveness may diminish if overused or triggered falsely
- Requires power, detection equipment, and maintenance
topics.references: Li, J. Q., et al. (2025). Strategies and technologies for warning at highway–rail grade crossings (NCHRP Project 17-122, Final Report). National Cooperative Highway Research Program.

topics.title: Path-Crossing Alignment Angle Adjustment
topics.description: Re-aligning sidewalks or shared-use paths so that users cross the tracks at approximately a 90-degree angle, improving sight distance and reducing the chance of wheels catching in flangeways.
topics.notablePractices:
- Provide smooth horizontal curves and adequate sight distances
- Coordinate with refuge islands or channelization where needed
- Ensure drainage and surface transitions remain comfortable
topics.advantages:
- Reduces risk of wheel entrapment and falls at skewed crossings
- Encourages users to look toward train approach directions
- Can be combined with other geometric and surface treatments
topics.drawbacks:
- May require additional right-of-way or reconstruction
- Can introduce awkward path geometry if poorly designed
- Design effort is higher than simple signing-only treatments
topics.references: Federal Railroad Administration. (2019). Highway-rail crossing handbook (3rd ed.). U.S. Department of Transportation.

topics.title: Flangeway Gap Filler
topics.description: Resilient inserts or special rail-embedded panels used to reduce the open flangeway gap at pedestrian and bicycle crossings while still accommodating train wheels.
topics.notablePractices:
- Verify compatibility with wheel loads and track maintenance
- Inspect regularly for damage, settlement, or ice accumulation
- Coordinate with ADA requirements for mobility devices
topics.advantages:
- Reduces risk of bicycle and wheelchair wheels getting caught
- Improves comfort and confidence for non-motorized users
- Can be retrofitted at some existing crossings
topics.drawbacks:
- Higher installation and replacement costs than plain asphalt
- Performance can be sensitive to climate and debris
- Not appropriate for all track classes or speeds
topics.references: Harkey, D. L., et al. (2004). PEDSAFE: Pedestrian safety guide and countermeasure selection system (Report No. FHWA-SA-04-003). Federal Highway Administration.

topics.title: Lower Pedestrian Warning Devices
topics.description: Pedestrian-scale flashing beacons, signals, or signs mounted closer to eye level for people on foot rather than only at vehicle height, improving noticeability of warnings.
topics.notablePractices:
- Follow MUTCD guidance for sign placement and height
- Avoid cluttering the approach with too many messages
- Combine with pavement markings at the decision point
topics.advantages:
- Makes warnings more visible in the pedestrian visual field
- Can clarify that the device applies to sidewalk or path users
- Relatively low-cost compared to major geometric changes
topics.drawbacks:
- Requires power and periodic maintenance of devices
- May be ignored if not clearly linked to train operations
- Visual clutter can reduce effectiveness if overdone
topics.references: Federal Highway Administration. (2023). Manual on uniform traffic control devices for streets and highways (11th ed., Part 9: Traffic control for bicycle facilities). U.S. Department of Transportation.

topics.title: Sidewalk Pavement Markings
topics.description: Text, symbols, or arrows applied directly to sidewalks or paths near crossings to indicate where to wait, where to look, or which route to follow to a legal crossing.
topics.notablePractices:
- Use simple, high-contrast symbols that are intuitive
- Place markings at the decision point, not far upstream
- Refresh regularly where snow and de-icing wear surfaces
topics.advantages:
- Low-cost way to reinforce desired behavior
- Can support multilingual communication through symbols
- Flexible and easy to pilot or adjust over time
topics.drawbacks:
- Subject to wear and fading, especially in harsh climates
- Less effective in low-light or cluttered conditions
- Should not be relied on as the only treatment at high-risk sites
topics.references: Zegeer, C. V., et al. (2004). PEDSAFE: Pedestrian safety guide and countermeasure selection system (Report No. FHWA-SA-04-003). Federal Highway Administration.

topics.title: Public Messaging
topics.description: Broad communications campaigns using social media, posters, PSAs, and community outreach to remind people to stay off the tracks and use legal crossings.
topics.notablePractices:
- Tailor messages to local audiences and common behaviors
- Coordinate with schools, employers, and community groups
- Reinforce messages during special events or service changes
topics.advantages:
- Builds long-term safety culture beyond a single location
- Can be deployed regionally at relatively low cost
- Complements enforcement and engineering measures
topics.drawbacks:
- Effects are diffuse and hard to measure directly
- Less effective without visible on-the-ground changes
- Messages can be ignored if overused or not refreshed
topics.references: Operation Lifesaver, Inc. (2025). Rail safety education programs. https://oli.org

topics.title: Post-Incident Response
topics.description: Structured protocols for responding to pedestrian or bicycle incidents or near-misses at crossings, including investigation, data collection, and follow-up improvements.
topics.notablePractices:
- Capture consistent data on circumstances and contributing factors
- Engage railroads, roadway agencies, and law enforcement
- Translate findings into a documented mitigation plan
topics.advantages:
- Ensures that serious events lead to systemic learning
- Can reveal design and operations issues not apparent in normal conditions
- Supports grant applications and prioritization of investments
topics.drawbacks:
- Requires staff time and cross-agency coordination
- May be sensitive when litigation or public controversy is involved
- Without funding, findings may not translate into action
topics.references: Federal Railroad Administration. (2025). Highway-rail grade crossing and trespassing research. U.S. Department of Transportation.

topics.title: Detectable Warning Surfaces at Crossings
topics.description: Truncated-dome tactile surfaces placed on approaches to tracks to provide a non-visual warning to people with vision disabilities that they are entering the track danger zone.
topics.notablePractices:
- Place at a consistent offset from the nearest rail
- Coordinate with local ADA standards and good practice
- Ensure adequate contrast and drainage around the panels
topics.advantages:
- Critical accessibility cue for blind and low-vision users
- Clearly defines the boundary between sidewalk and track area
- Widely understood due to use at curb ramps and stations
topics.drawbacks:
- Poor installation can create trip or ponding issues
- Panels may need periodic replacement when worn or damaged
- Does not by itself prevent risky behavior by sighted users

images.alt: Detectable Warning Surfaces at Crossings illustration
images.caption: Detectable Warning Surfaces at Crossings

topics.references: U.S. Access Board. (2002). Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) accessibility guidelines for buildings and facilities. U.S. Access Board.

topics.title: Bike-Friendly Crossing Surface Panels
topics.description: Rubber, composite, or concrete panels that provide a smooth, skid-resistant surface across the tracks with minimal gaps or steps that could destabilize bicycles or wheelchairs.
topics.notablePractices:
- Coordinate panel selection with track structure and maintenance
- Provide transitions that match adjacent pavement elevations
- Inspect regularly for settlement and surface damage
topics.advantages:
- Reduces single-bicycle crashes related to track crossings
- Improves comfort for wheelchairs, strollers, and carts
- Can reduce long-term maintenance of crossing surfaces
topics.drawbacks:
- Higher initial cost than simple asphalt approaches
- Requires specialized installation procedures
- Damaged panels can quickly degrade user comfort and safety
topics.references: Ogden, B. D., & Cooper, C. (2019). Highway-rail crossing handbook (3rd ed.). Federal Highway Administration & Federal Railroad Administration.

topics.title: Dismount and Walk Zone
topics.description: Zones at complex or skewed crossings where cyclists are instructed or required to dismount and walk their bikes across the tracks for safety.
topics.notablePractices:
- Use clear symbols and pavement markings, not just text
- Provide a short, direct crossing distance to minimize delay
- Consider as an interim measure until design fixes are feasible
topics.advantages:
- Addresses high-risk geometries where quick fixes are needed
- Simple to communicate once markings and signs are in place
- Can reduce crash rates at problem crossings
topics.drawbacks:
- Compliance can be low without strong design cues or enforcement
- Can be frustrating for confident or high-volume riders
- Does not address root geometric issues by itself
topics.references: Zegeer, C. V., et al. (2004). PEDSAFE: Pedestrian safety guide and countermeasure selection system. Federal Highway Administration.

topics.title: Z-Gates / Maze Barriers
topics.description: Offset gates or railings that require users to make one or more turns before crossing the tracks, slowing travel and orienting them toward approaching trains.
topics.notablePractices:
- Design to accommodate wheelchairs, cargo bikes, and trailers
- Avoid creating pinch points that trap users between tracks
- Combine with clear sight lines toward train approach
topics.advantages:
- Slows users and encourages them to look for trains
- Creates a strong visual cue that a rail crossing is ahead
- Can be retrofitted to existing paths and sidewalks
topics.drawbacks:
- Can impede larger mobility devices if not designed carefully
- May be perceived as hostile or inconvenient
- Requires regular inspection to keep gates aligned and functional
topics.references: Ogden, B. D., & Cooper, C. (2019). Highway-rail crossing handbook (3rd ed.). Federal Highway Administration & Federal Railroad Administration.

topics.title: Pedestrian/Bicycle Refuge Island
topics.description: A protected waiting area between tracks or traffic lanes that allows pedestrians and cyclists to cross in stages rather than all at once.
topics.notablePractices:
- Provide detectable warnings at the track interface
- Ensure sufficient width for bikes, strollers, and wheelchairs
- Avoid creating sight obstructions for train crews or drivers
topics.advantages:
- Reduces pressure to “beat the train” or traffic
- Allows users to focus on one direction of traffic at a time
- Can be combined with medians and channelization
topics.drawbacks:
- Requires adequate corridor width
- Construction and drainage may be more complex
- Must be designed to prevent trapping users between tracks
topics.references: Blackburn, L., et al. (2022). Improving intersections for pedestrians and bicyclists (Report No. FHWA-SA-22-017). Federal Highway Administration.

topics.title: Path and Sidewalk Lighting at Crossings
topics.description: Focused lighting on sidewalks, paths, and the crossing surface that improves visibility of rails, gaps, markings, and warning devices during low-light conditions.
topics.notablePractices:
- Aim fixtures to avoid glare for train crews and motorists
- Use uniform lighting levels on approaches and at the crossing
- Consider adaptive or motion-activated lighting in low-volume areas
topics.advantages:
- Improves users’ ability to see hazards and warnings at night
- Enhances personal security near isolated crossings
- Can extend the usable hours of trails and paths safely
topics.drawbacks:
- Requires power supply and ongoing maintenance
- Poorly aimed lights can cause glare or light pollution
- Initial installation cost may be significant in remote locations

images.alt: Path and Sidewalk Lighting at Crossings illustration
images.caption: Path and Sidewalk Lighting at Crossings

topics.references: Ogden, B. D., & Cooper, C. (2019). Highway-rail crossing handbook (3rd ed.). Federal Highway Administration & Federal Railroad Administration.

topics.title: In-Pavement LED Path Warning
topics.description: LED modules embedded in or adjacent to the path surface that flash when a train is detected, placing the warning directly in the user’s line of sight.
topics.notablePractices:
- Coordinate activation with existing train detection systems
- Use robust, slip-resistant lenses suitable for snow and maintenance
- Test visibility in daytime and nighttime conditions
topics.advantages:
- Highly visible to users looking down at the path or a phone
- Ties the warning state directly to the crossing surface
- Can clarify which tracks or approach are active in complex layouts
topics.drawbacks:
- Higher capital and maintenance cost than conventional signals
- Vulnerable to damage from plows and resurfacing equipment
- Requires careful integration with signal control logic
topics.references: Li, J. Q., et al. (2025). Strategies and technologies for warning at highway–rail grade crossings (NCHRP Project 17-122, Final Report). National Cooperative Highway Research Program.

topics.title: Second Train Coming Indicator
topics.description: A supplemental indicator that activates when another train is approaching on a different track after the first train clears, warning users not to enter the crossing too early.
topics.notablePractices:
- Use simple, unambiguous legends or symbols
- Integrate with existing track circuits or train detection
- Educate the public about the meaning of the indicator
topics.advantages:
- Addresses a well-known high-risk scenario at multi-track crossings
- Can be added to existing active warning systems
- Helps prevent early entry when sightlines are blocked by a train
topics.drawbacks:
- Adds complexity to design, testing, and maintenance
- Benefits are limited at single-track locations
- Requires user understanding to be effective
topics.references: Ogden, B. D., & Cooper, C. (2019). Highway-rail crossing handbook (3rd ed.). Federal Highway Administration & Federal Railroad Administration.

topics.title: Trail and Sidewalk Fencing Along ROW
topics.description: Continuous fencing or railings between trails/sidewalks and the rail right-of-way, except at legal crossings, to keep people off the tracks and ballast.
topics.notablePractices:
- Extend fencing past the immediate crossing to intercept desire lines
- Provide clearly signed and accessible legal crossings
- Plan for emergency and maintenance access points
topics.advantages:
- Strong deterrent to casual trespass along tracks
- Helps consolidate crossing locations where treatments can be focused
- Can reduce debris and encroachment into the right-of-way
topics.drawbacks:
- Visually and physically separates communities if not paired with access
- Installation and upkeep costs over long corridors
- Fence ends or gaps can become new trespass locations

images.alt: Trail and Sidewalk Fencing Along ROW illustration
images.caption: Trail and Sidewalk Fencing Along ROW

topics.references: Federal Railroad Administration. (2010). Community trespass prevention guide. U.S. Department of Transportation.

topics.title: Ped/Bike Crossing Risk Audit
topics.description: A structured field review process focused on pedestrian and bicycle conditions at crossings, scoring risk factors and prioritizing locations for treatment.
topics.notablePractices:
- Use a standardized checklist informed by current guidance
- Include observations at different times of day and year
- Integrate audit results into capital and maintenance programs
topics.advantages:
- Provides a systematic way to compare many crossings
- Helps justify investments based on documented risk
- Can incorporate community observations and near-miss data
topics.drawbacks:
- Requires staff or consultant time to conduct
- Results may be subjective without clear scoring guidance
- Can be frustrating if findings are not linked to funding
topics.references: Texas Department of Transportation. (2023). Pedestrian and bicycle safety resources: PEDSAFE and BIKESAFE. https://www.txdot.gov

topics.title: Near-Miss Reporting for Peds/Bikes
topics.description: Simple reporting tools—such as QR codes, web forms, or apps—that allow users to report close calls, falls, or observed risky behavior at specific crossings.
topics.notablePractices:
- Make reporting links visible at or near crossings
- Provide a simple form that captures time, behavior, and conditions
- Close the feedback loop by sharing summary findings publicly
topics.advantages:
- Captures safety concerns before serious crashes occur
- Engages the community as partners in safety
- Can highlight issues that crash data alone would miss
topics.drawbacks:
- Self-reported data may be incomplete or biased
- Requires staff capacity for data review and follow-up
- Expectations for quick fixes may exceed available resources
topics.references: Operation Lifesaver, Inc. (2025). Rail safety outreach materials. https://oli.org

topics.title: Tactile Strips at Station Platforms
topics.description: Continuous tactile warning strips along platform edges to alert passengers with vision disabilities that they are close to the platform drop-off.
topics.notablePractices:
- Maintain consistent offset from platform edge per standards
- Use high-contrast colors to aid low-vision users
- Keep strips free of snow, ice, and debris
topics.advantages:
- Essential ADA feature for safe independent travel
- Helps prevent falls from the platform edge
- Familiar treatment across many transit systems
topics.drawbacks:
- Requires ongoing maintenance and periodic replacement
- Can be slippery if the wrong materials are used
- Does not address crowding or behavior on platforms by itself

images.alt: Tactile Strips at Station Platforms illustration
images.caption: Tactile Strips at Station Platforms

topics.references: U.S. Access Board. (2002). Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) accessibility guidelines for buildings and facilities. U.S. Access Board.

topics.title: Station Platform Gap Fillers
topics.description: Fixed or deployable elements that reduce the horizontal or vertical gap between train doors and the platform, improving access and reducing trip risk.
topics.notablePractices:
- Coordinate design with rolling stock, door locations, and curvature
- Provide fail-safe behavior if mechanical devices are used
- Inspect regularly for damage or misalignment
topics.advantages:
- Improves accessibility for wheelchair users, strollers, and people with luggage
- Reduces risk of feet or mobility devices slipping into the gap
- Supports level boarding where full reconstruction is not feasible
topics.drawbacks:
- Mechanical systems can add complexity and maintenance needs
- Not all locations can accommodate full gap reduction
- May require operational changes to ensure trains berth precisely
topics.references: Federal Transit Administration. (2011). Transit cooperative research program report 145: Reinventing the urban rail passenger experience.

topics.title: Designated Bike Waiting Zone at Stations
topics.description: Clearly marked areas on platforms or concourses where people with bicycles are encouraged to wait for trains, separated from general waiting areas and boarding flows.
topics.notablePractices:
- Place zones near doors that permit bicycle boarding
- Provide clear pavement markings and signage
- Coordinate with train interior layouts and bike storage policies
topics.advantages:
- Reduces conflicts between bikes and other passengers
- Makes expectations clear for where bikes should queue
- Can simplify operations and speed dwell times
topics.drawbacks:
- Requires space that may be limited at narrow platforms
- Effectiveness depends on user awareness and compliance
- May need adjustments as ridership patterns change

images.alt: Designated Bike Waiting Zone at Stations illustration
images.caption: Designated Bike Waiting Zone at Stations

topics.references: National Association of City Transportation Officials. (2014). Transit street design guide. Island Press.

topics.title: Clear Signage and Wayfinding for Bike Boarding at Stations
topics.description: Signs, maps, and floor markings that show where bikes may board, which train cars permit bikes, and the preferred circulation routes through stations.
topics.notablePractices:
- Use consistent symbols for bicycles across the system
- Provide information at entrances, ticketing, and platforms
- Coordinate with online trip planners and printed materials
topics.advantages:
- Reduces confusion and conflicts at doors and on platforms
- Helps new riders understand how to bring bikes on transit
- Can be updated incrementally as policies or operations change
topics.drawbacks:
- Requires upkeep as operating patterns and fleets evolve
- Overly complex signage can overwhelm users
- Less effective without supporting station design and policies

images.alt: Clear Signage and Wayfinding for Bike Boarding at Stations illustration
images.caption: Clear Signage and Wayfinding for Bike Boarding at Stations

topics.references: Federal Transit Administration. (2010). Bicycle access to public transportation: A synthesis of transit practice. Transportation Research Board.

topics.title: No-Ride Rules on Platforms
topics.description: Rules, signage, and sometimes enforcement actions that require cyclists to walk, not ride, while on platforms, concourses, and station approaches.
topics.notablePractices:
- Combine signs with pavement markings and tactile cues
- Enforce rules consistently during busy periods
- Communicate the rationale as protecting vulnerable users
topics.advantages:
- Reduces collision and fall risk in crowded station areas
- Clarifies expectations for multi-modal users
- Complements bike channels, elevators, and other access features
topics.drawbacks:
- Compliance may be low without design reinforcement
- Can be perceived as unfriendly to cyclists if not well messaged
- Requires coordination between rail operators and security staff
topics.references: National Association of City Transportation Officials. (2014). Transit street design guide. Island Press.

topics.title: Bike Channels on Stairs
topics.description: Narrow ramps or channels along one side of a stairway that allow users to roll a bicycle up or down while walking, rather than carrying it.
topics.notablePractices:
- Provide adequate handrail clearance and tread depth
- Use slip-resistant, durable materials
- Sign channels clearly and keep them free of debris
topics.advantages:
- Makes stations more accessible to people with bikes
- Reduces conflicts in elevators used by wheelchair users
- Lower cost than installing additional elevators or ramps
topics.drawbacks:
- Not accessible for people who cannot manage stairs
- May encourage bikes on stairs where they were previously discouraged
- Requires careful detailing to avoid tripping hazards
topics.references: Federal Highway Administration. (2006). Shared-use paths: Design, function, and safety (FHWA-HRT-05-137).

topics.title: Vertical Access Improvements – ADA Ramps and Elevators
topics.description: Fully accessible ramps and elevators that connect street, concourse, and platform levels, reducing the need for at-grade track crossings or awkward stair carries.
topics.notablePractices:
- Design for redundancy where possible to avoid single points of failure
- Provide clear wayfinding from street to accessible routes
- Maintain equipment proactively to minimize downtime
topics.advantages:
- Expands independent access for people with disabilities
- Reduces incentives to take unsafe shortcuts across the tracks
- Supports luggage, strollers, and other wheeled devices
topics.drawbacks:
- High capital and lifecycle costs
- Elevator outages can undermine reliability and trust
- Ramps require significant space in constrained environments

images.alt: Vertical Access Improvements – ADA Ramps and Elevators illustration
images.caption: Vertical Access Improvements – ADA Ramps and Elevators

topics.references: U.S. Access Board. (2006). ADA accessibility guidelines for transportation facilities. U.S. Access Board.

topics.title: Hostile Landscaping
topics.description: Use of dense shrubs, thorny plantings, rocks, or other natural features to make it difficult and uncomfortable to cut across the right-of-way at informal trespass points.
topics.notablePractices:
- Coordinate with ecological goals and maintenance practices
- Avoid plantings that obscure sightlines near crossings
- Pair with legal alternative routes or crossings
topics.advantages:
- Provides a visually softer alternative to fencing in some contexts
- Can blend with corridor aesthetics and habitat goals
- Helps reinforce that the corridor is not a walkable shortcut
topics.drawbacks:
- May be perceived as hostile or exclusionary if overdone
- Requires ongoing vegetation management
- Ineffective against determined trespassers on its own
topics.references: Federal Railroad Administration. (2010). Community trespass prevention guide. U.S. Department of Transportation.

topics.title: Parallel Trail Along ROW
topics.description: A separated shared-use path constructed parallel to the tracks but outside the railroad right-of-way, providing a legal, comfortable route that replaces informal walking in the ballast or along the ties.
topics.notablePractices:
- Provide safe, well-marked connections to legal crossings
- Maintain separation with fencing or landscaping where needed
- Coordinate ownership, easements, and maintenance responsibilities
topics.advantages:
- Converts trespass desire lines into safe, attractive facilities
- Supports active transportation and first/last mile access
- Can be integrated with greenways and linear parks
topics.drawbacks:
- Requires right-of-way, design, and capital funding
- May raise concerns about new users near the corridor
- Needs clear maintenance roles between agencies
topics.references: Federal Highway Administration. (2006). Evaluation of safety, design, and operation of shared-use paths (FHWA-HRT-05-137).

topics.title: AI Data Collection
topics.description: Use of fixed or train-mounted cameras and artificial intelligence to automatically detect trespass, near-miss events, or user volumes at crossings and along the right-of-way.
topics.notablePractices:
- Protect privacy through aggregation and masking as needed
- Validate AI outputs with field observations
- Use findings to prioritize engineering, education, and enforcement
topics.advantages:
- Allows continuous monitoring without full-time human observers
- Can reveal spatial and temporal patterns of risky behavior
- Supports data-driven grant applications and program evaluation
topics.drawbacks:
- Requires upfront investment in hardware and analytics
- Algorithms must be tuned to local conditions and weather
- Data governance and privacy concerns must be addressed
topics.references: Zaman, A., et al. (2019). Artificial intelligence–aided automated detection of railroad trespassing events. Transportation Research Record, 2673(10), 103–114.

topics.title: Grade Separation
topics.description: Projects that completely separate pedestrian and bicycle movements from the tracks using overpasses, underpasses, or relocated facilities, eliminating at-grade conflict.
topics.notablePractices:
- Design approaches with good visibility, ramps, and lighting
- Ensure routes feel safe and direct to encourage use
- Coordinate with freight and passenger rail operations
topics.advantages:
- Eliminates at-grade train conflict for non-motorized users
- Reduces exposure to both train and roadway traffic
- Can provide landmark civic spaces and connections
topics.drawbacks:
- Very high capital cost and long delivery timelines
- May introduce out-of-direction travel if poorly aligned
- Requires ongoing maintenance and may have security concerns
topics.references: Federal Railroad Administration & Federal Highway Administration. (2019). Highway-rail crossing handbook (3rd ed.). U.S. Department of Transportation.
